story:
Me

I am a writer, wanderer and global minded spirit seeking support in finishing, editing and publishing my autobiographical literary work. Why? Because you just can't make this stuff up.

I was born in Tehran, Iran, to a Syrian mother and an African American father during the Islamic Revolution that thrust the country away from modernization and into the waiting arms of an old familiar, tyrannical lover. Enghelab (revolution) first appealed to the people with hyacinths and verse, serenading with rosewater promises. Pressing slights and unfulfilled legacies, Iran was eventually persuaded. Iran found itself honeymooning on the beaches of sharia, watching tumult and sunset. Iran consummated with chadors and curfews, whispering sweet nothings, hostages, execution. Iran sighed breaths of fire (bombs), igniting the geopolitical landscape in its fervor until the sun came up. Chaos was conceived.

The imamate pounded its oil-barreled chest with both fists and Iran's political structure mutated overnight- from monarchial tyranny to Islamic patriarchy and staunch theocracy. Once in power, the revolutionary forces obliterated opposition and began to eat its own children. I was conceived in this environment and smuggled out of Iran as a toddler by my American father. From what I'm able to discern, (my family remains mute and forgetful for the most part, save my grandmother) we escaped under dire circumstances. Family members were murdered or simply never heard from again. Others had their livelihoods seized by the imamate, and still others relocated to Australia. 

I was raised in California suburbia, where I was forced to forge an identity without much guidance in a multicultural void where disparate cultural identities were vilified. Turmoil, insecurity, even violence colored my teenage years and somehow I found my way to the University of Southern California in Los Angeles. I studied Political Science and went on to work as an editor for Robert Shapiro before realizing my desire to create stories. I began writing in earnest in my 20s and found that my creative works all seem to take root in my mother's homeland. Tired of Los Angeles and unable to ignore the wanderlust that I inherited from my father, I turned my life upside down. In 2009 I moved to Paris, went back to school and earned a Masters in Middle Eastern and Islamic studies. Turns out a passport doesnâ€™t help you outrun your demons. One morning in Autumn I woke up in French hospital bed, surrounded by medical staff with every kind of tube coming out of my body. That day was a pivotal one. It was the day I swore I would exorcise the demons that had caused me so much suffering and kept me wandering the sand dunes of mediocrity. I have since slaughtered my demons and made hats out of their heads.

As in France under the Bourbons, Russia under the Romanovs, and Iran under the Pahlavis, America is now undergoing its own dramatic restructuring, a process that mirrors my own progression from lost soul to writer and educator. This personal metamorphosis is still under way; I'm moving to Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, in March of 2012 to help grow the worldâ€™s largest all-female university, to teach, develop curriculum and hopefully help create a political science department. (Letâ€™s start with that. Hopes for an art program in one of the most culturally repressive regimes on Earth might be a bit overzealous even for me). The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia has recently passed legislation that will grant women suffrage and the right to drive. It's finally understood that KSA, despite having the world's fastest growing economy, can never have a truly thriving nation when 60% of the population remains idle. Thank you, Jesus! (Muhammad?) These are exciting times in the Middle East and I canâ€™t wait to jump in and be a part of this transition, even if from under an abaya (Saudi version of a burqa). Off to my genetic homeland I go- where I plan to spend any and all spare time writing, writing, writing! in order to complete my story, have it edited and hopefully published!


My story will include:

Why I think my father has worked in intelligence at some point, despite his denials.

Accounts of the toads I've kissed- some renowned, some criminals, others just plain crazy, but still haven't found my match.

Accounts of experiences from every part of the social strata imaginable, on several continents.


So what is the Gift, you ask? It is several things, one being the gratitude I have in knowing that had I been raised in another culture I would not be encouraged to pursue my artistic pursuits.


I ask for your support in creating the synthesis that is my life: welding the various parts of myself, my heritage, my cultures, my art and my roles as working writer, educator, and humanist. Your kindness will help fund writing time and pay for an editor to help me polish this work by Summer 2012. You are appreciated beyond what could be expressed with pen. 

The Impact

I hope to impact, inspire and educate through my writing, my trials, travels, work and imagination.


What I Need & What You Get

I'm offering a copy of my written work to those who contribute to the costs associated with hiring an editor in order to get published. Being a working writer is not only the goal here, it is my only dream. Thank you for supporting me.


Other Ways You Can Help

Pray. I'm going to need prayers when I move to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia!

story:
What's It All About?

Woody Allen once wrote "It's not that I'm afraid to die, I just don't want to be there when it happens." His words probably mirror the thoughts of most human beings alive today: we try to ignore the fact of our own mortality by viewing death as something that  happens to other people, hiding the concept beyond our sight by employing euphemisms such as "passed on" (or with pets, "went to sleep"). And no wonder – over the past few hundred years, humanity has gone from a blind religious faith in an afterlife, to a modern scientific vision of complete personal annihilation at the time of physical death (not to mention a life that has no overall consequence within the vast scale of the cosmos).
 
For too long, the debate over the possibility of some sort of hereafter has been dominated by these two diametrically opposed views. So much so, that the general public is not aware that there is some very good evidence supporting the idea that, at the time of our physical death, some part of us 'continues on'. In the book I am currently writing, I will tell the story of how, for more than a hundred years, scientists have been finding evidence for consciousness continuing on beyond death; people have been recounting their own personal encounters with 'the other side of the veil'; and some of the world's best thinkers have been suggesting that human consciousness may be far more than just the accidental by-product of a flesh-and-blood brain. The evidence may not be concrete, but it's certainly enough for any person to hold a 'rational' belief that we all continue on in some way.

The ramifications of this possibility are profound for society, and deserve wider contemplation and discussion. What if our loved ones continue on beyond death, and we will someday be reunited? Should we pay more attention to the accounts of near-death experiencers, who are told on the 'other side' that the key components of life are to love and gain knowledge? And, if there is an afterlife, what does this mean for the way we approach our own deaths?
 
I have written about these topics in short-form for almost 15 years now on my popular website The Daily Grail, and in a number of books I have already published (see for example this article). I am an experienced publisher, having released a dozen books already through my independent publishing house, Daily Grail Publishing. Please help me bring this topic to a wider audience, in more detailed form, by supporting this book project.
 

What I Need, And What You'll Get

I am already currently working on the book (20,000 words down at the time of writing), and it will be released no matter what level of support I receive - this has been a personal quest of mine for quite some time now. The goal of this pre-publication funding is to make the book as good as it can possibly be, by allowing funds for absolutely comprehensive research (tracking down/purchasing source documents, interviewing key people, freeing up time for writing, etc.) and book design/manufacture expenses. As such, I've made a very conservative estimate of $5000 as a goal to do this, though my ideal funding level is higher. However, I appreciate whatever support is offered by those interested in seeing this book published.

To raise the necessary funds, I'm offering a number of pre-publication packages for various levels of funding support, allowing YOU to become a co-creator of this book! For just $5, you can get one of the eBook editions (PDF, Kindle or ePub), DRM-free (meaning you can copy it around wherever you want, rather than being restricted). For a few dollars more, I'll send the pack of all 3 eBook editions, so you can read on whichever device you want (your computer, Kindle, iPad etc). For $20, you can get the eBook pack, and share it with/gift it to TEN other people, absolutely guilt-free. While there will be a paperback edition, I can't compete on price with online booksellers to offer a competitively-priced offer, but I am offering a $60 pack of a signed paperback plus the eBook gift pack for anybody that likes that price range. do offer two higher level packages for those that really want to help out, with the reward of limited edition hardcover editions, signed by myself, and with your name listed in the book as a key contributor (as well as the eBook pack) - if interested, see the side panel for the two packages on offer. I'm aiming to deliver these packages by November, with the book out for general sale before Christmas. All packages include paid (standard) postage expense to wherever you are.

Got a Story to Tell?

Beyond financial contributions, I'd be just as excited about content contributions. Are you a NDEr, or have some other story to tell about dying and the afterlife? Please do get in touch with me, I would love to hear from you!

Help Spread the Word!

If you're ready to sign up and help bring this book to publication, thanks so much - it's a real pleasure and honour having you on board as a co-creator! I'm sure it's a win-win for everyone involved, and you'll enjoy the finished product immensely. But if even the $5 eBook is beyond your finances, I hope you can at least help me spread the word to others who might be interested, either through email or social media, or by using the share tools provided by IndieGoGo. I truly believe that this topic deserves more serious consideration. In the end, no matter what your spiritual/religious view (or lack thereof), we should all strive to do right by others, while living life to the fullest. But if we are attempting to understand who we are, and where we are going, in the grand scale of things, it's also important that we consider the idea that our consciousness may survive death. This book will be the ultimate resource for those who want to learn more.

story:
Who

Mid-Cities Community Church is sending a team of 10 to Uganda and Ethiopia.

 

What

Here is the brief description of the organizations and communities we will be serving:

60Feet - Bringing hope and restoration to imprisoned children. (sixtyfeet.org)

Return Ministries International - Uganda has been ravaged by war and disease. Return Ministries founded a children's home as a response to the overwhelming number of orphaned and vulnerable children and women.

Bring Love In - A community in Addis Ababa that pairs orphans given to the organization by the authorities with widows from within local Christian church communities to create new families in Ethiopia.

Project 61 - Their primary focus is to partner with local Ethiopian organizations in underprivileged areas to develop communities and their residents.

Korah - Korah is one of the poorest communities in Ethiopia. It is a leper colony that houses over 90,000 people living in houses usually no larger than 12x12 square feet.

When

June 5th - 15th

 

Buy a Shirt! 

The t-shirt perks feature a painstakingly hand drawn design on a very nice American Apparel T. We wanted to design something that spoke of more than just our mission in Africa. It is a simple idea that could transform the world. 

*Note: If you want more than one shirt, just donate the proper amount for everything. I will be sending a form to get sizing to everyone soon!

Check it out:

Here are renderings from the screenprinter:

And the non v-neck available in kids and adult sizes:

 

Photo Session!

Hire me for a 30 minute photo session. View some of my previous work here: gallery.timedwards.info. You can even wear your t-shirt! 

 

Other ways you can help:

If you can't contribute, it's okay! We still need you to join us in prayer and promotion! Share this page anywhere you can! 

 

Tax Attention!

Donations made on this page don't yield tax savings!! You can donate on the Mid-Cities official donation page to recieve a tax deductable reciept.

story:
While promoting my series BOYSTOWN at this year's Market Days, my bag containing my MacBook and some personal effects, including a journal of my writing, was stolen. No one can put a price on the stolen intellectual property that is lost forever or the sentimental value of the MacBook being a Christmas gift from my mom. My Macbook had no less than 5 plays in development and the intellctual property for nonprofit arts organizations and my day job that were in development.

 

Like many struggling artists, I work a day job to make ends meet and live with little luxury. This sort of loss is devastating, not only financially, but artistically. I'm reaching out to my family, friends, and fans to see if they can help me replace the MacBook and extremely expensive software that was stolen. There is no greater way to ruin a writer than by taking his means of communication and the works he had in development. Help me continue to create stories.

 

Every little bit, even $1 can help. Please share with your family and friends and see if they can help too. Thanks so much for all the love and support!

 

Danny B

story:
As a firm believer in and catalyst of grassroots-engineered ventures, I am eager to kick off a self-made literary mini-tour to share and promote my debut fiction novel: Broken Land, a Brooklyn Tale (see book description below). With the help of my publisher, CSF (an international, little-engine-that-could press, which is doing its part to keep the spirit of independent publishing alive and kicking) I intend to hit the Left Coast to do readings at bookstores/venues.


L.A.  and San Francisco, and potentially Denver en route, would be the cities where I would give readings.  I am especially motivated to conduct a "live-action" mini-tour, because, in this day and age of cyberspatial expedience and virtual networking, there's something old-school satisying about people, gathered together in a room or basement or bar, in the name of literary kinship (A Moveable Feast meets this-ain't-your-Papa's-Beat-generation).  I have the contacts to help foster this sort of kinship, and I have a publisher who is willing to engage bookstores on my behalf ... what I lack are the funds to finance my word-is-bond mission. 

Cost breakdown would include: Train fare (I'd be shipping out from Albuquerque, NM, and have researched and calculated the train fares that would cover the places where I'd need to go), low-budget accommodation expenses, food costs, and money to fulfill the "perk reward" obligations. 


My plan woud be to leave for about a two to three-week period in November.  If I fell short of my goal of $2,500, then I would revise my plan and use the money I made to give readings exclusively in L.A. (or perhaps even shift direction and set up engagements in New York, my hometown).     

In a crystal-clear nutshell: I put a lot of time and energy into writing my novel, and now want to put as much time and energy into supporting its existence outside myself.  In the immortal words of Groucho Marx: "Outside of a dog a book is man's best friend.  Inside of a dog it's too dark to read."  

Book blurb:

Existential noir with a pop-cultural slant, Broken Land, a Brooklyn Tale chronicles the urban exploits of wanna-be sleuth and slapstick film buff, Salvatore Massimo Lunezzi.  Prompted by an enigmatic phone call from a writer-friend claiming to be dead, Lunezzi launches an investigation that leads him to Ghostwriters, Inc., a company selling inspiration to struggling writers through the medium of “ghosting.” From Buster Keaton to Arthur Rimbaud; a boozy dwarf to a mysterious femme fatale; hip hop to the madness of art; Lunezzi is drawn deeper and deeper into a Coney Island of the soul.

For more personal information on me, reviews of the novel, audio/video footage, etc., please visit my Amazon Author page: amazon.com/author/johnbiscello.  There's also my author page on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/inkslinger1974?ref=hl, and a page for the novel itself: http://www.facebook.com/brokenlandabrooklyntale?ref=hl. My publisher's website: csfpublishing.com.

story:
These are difficult times for the guidebook publishing industry, with too many titles chasing too few readers. So even a guide to Beijing that receives reviews like these may wait a long time for a second edition:

More than comprehensive. ~ Holiday Asia

Fun but authoritative, the book is written in the strong voice of someone who loves poking around Beijing's hutongs, buzzing with pleasure at each new find... old China hands will even learn a thing or two. And the well-worn tourist attractions like the Forbidden City are given a new spin in a refreshing break from all the been-there-seen-that guides on the shelf. ~ Time

This positive reception did eventually convince new owners of the publisher to commission a second edition. But after months had been spent tramping the streets of the Chinese capital and more in revising the text from start to finish, shrinking guidebook sales meant plans to cover China more comprehensively were cancelled and the rights to the text released.

Three other publishers expressed an interest in picking up the nearly complete work, but in the current economic climate eventually decided against publishing a comprehensive guide.

Bring Beijing back to life

This finally provides an opportunity to produce a really satisfying guide to Beijing, and one that visitors really need; one free of the restrictions that commercial publishers tend to impose.

Some of these restrictions are entirely sensible; for instance, keeping the number of pages down so as to reduce production costs and keep cover prices competitive. But some destinations just need more space to cover properly than others. Few countries change faster than China, yet publishers often request that a guide should be updated but without changing anything, in order to keep costs down.

While any visitor capable of tackling Paris without French can easily tackle Beijing without Mandarin, the tool they need to help them do this must be rather more detailed and sophisticated. Some publishers refuse to include Chinese characters, or severely restrict their numbers, making the book useless to readers who for instance need to show the characters for their destinations to taxi drivers and ticket sellers, or communicate their orders to waitresses.   Even the best-informed and most diligent Mandarin-speaking writers struggle to squeeze Beijing and everything that visitors need to know into the straightjacket of house styles and formats originally developed for European or North American destinations, but which the publisher insists may not be even slightly altered.

This project is all about not letting years of research go to waste. It's about completing the revision and expansion of an already well-reviewed book, putting its information and advice into the hands of as many visitors to Beijing as possible, and doing so for the lowest possible cover price. It's about making one more complete revision of the text before issuing it in a format especially devised for the needs of Chinese destinations and China travellers.

As the saying goes, if you want something done properly, do it yourself.

Journalism

Because that's what a really good guidebook should be.   The highest standards of accuracy and detail need to be brought to the text with every fact double-checked.

Despite guide book cover claims to the contrary, most publishers fail to do any significant amount of fact-checking.   And the text should be more than the hearsay and superficial generalisations common to many guides. It should include a wealth of readable background detail, observation, and original research. There's no need for guidebooks to be entirely trivial, to sugar-coat real life, or to highlight only the most appealing aspects of a destination with text that's been manipulated to match carefully cropped and Photoshopped images.

A guidebook should be something you reach for not only for opening hours, ticket prices, and transport information, but because of its readable background material, engaging stories, and fresh research that together advance enjoyment and understanding of a destination.   As Time said of the first edition:

A great guidebook... an infectious, informative read.

The second will be nearly twice the size, and the intention is that it should be twice as good.

Why ask for so little?

Obviously $5,000 is not remotely enough to cover the costs of several weeks' research in Beijing, not to mention further time at the keyboard and the necessary fact-checking, proof-reading, editing, and web page design, all of which are best done by those who know how, leaving me to concentrate on the text.

But there's a determination to get this done, and it seems best to look for a very modest contribution and then try to exceed that target if at all possible.

Publishers now typically pay a flat fee for a city guide of only about $8,000, so it's perhaps unsurprising that few well-qualified writers want to tackle this work, and that many guidebooks suffer as their authors attempt to complete them as quickly as possible.

But in this case, $8,000 would actually be very helpful in enhancing the amount of professional assistance to be used, and beyond that in sending out review copies and generating the publicity that will see the book in more people's hands. If we exceed $8000 then delivery of all copies to those choosing a $50 perk or higher will be post-free.

More funding still would also allow for updates to be incorporated swiftly in the months after first publication—one of the benefits of using print-on-demand technology.   $15,000+ would improve the book further, and make it possible to produce multiple updates, perhaps to print parts of the work as standalone volumes intended as supplements to other guides or to produce a companion volume on two- to three-day trips from Beijing or to revise and reissue China: The Silk Routes.

In general, the more funds, the better the results will be.  

The perks

This project is about not letting useful information go to waste, but putting it into the hands of as many people as possible. So the rewards take the form of the book itself, or the book with added extras.   It will be an 8.5" x 5.5" trade paperback, and looks likely to run to nearly 700 pages in the new design, with no space wasted on pretty pictures. Its contents include:

  • Fuller details of more sights of interest than any other current guide; several walking routes around little-visited sections of traditional housing and along less-known sections of the Great Wall; descriptions of multiple day trips into the surrounding countryside with information on travel options from public transport, through Chinese bus tours, to one-day taxi hires; all with detailed directions in both English and in Chinese characters, and GPS data 

  • Reading on everything: the lives of the palace eunuchs; corruption in China's modern art scene; the damage caused by UNESCO World Heritage Listing in China; myths about the Great Wall; the keeping of insects as pets; the true story of the Anglo-French destruction of the Summer Palace; the expulsion of Starbucks from the Forbidden City; the Boxer Rebellion, the former brothel quarter of Qian Men; and much more 

  • Extremely detailed practical advice on health, transport, visas, and more, enabling readers to tackle the city entirely on their own and without needing a word of Mandarin; and whether travelling independently or on a guided tour to avoid Beijing's common scams 

  • A shopping section with detailed advice on when to bargain in China and exactly how to do it there; details on how to obtain the best hotel rates and domestic air ticket prices, and how to negotiate day-trip hires with taxis. Any of this information might save visitors several multiples of the book’s cover price 

  • Comprehensive reviews of hostels and hotels from rock-bottom to palatial, and from revamped traditional courtyards to the spartan but business-friendly; a restaurant section that introduces the immense variety of Chinese regional cuisines now available in the capital and which provides all the characters necessary to order recommended dishes; further coverage of cheap street food, food courts, and the best from overseas 

  • A language section that provides all the characters visitors really need to get what they want; tone-marked pinyin and characters throughout to aid those who have learnt some Mandarin to be understood; a directory of all the attractions around each individual metro stop; a concise and readable history of the city; and much more. 

As the book’s final weight is currently unknown, postage and packing will be payable at net cost via PayPal at the time of dispatch (by your choice of surface, standard air mail, or faster means if preferred).   Canadians may also have to pay GST.

BONUS: If we exceed $8,000, then postage and packing will be FREE to all those who have chosen the $50 perk or higher.

Thanks are already due to Marina Dodis (www.marinadodis.com) for use of the only decent still images in an otherwise amateur video, and to professional cover designer, editor, web designer, and food critic friends and colleagues who have all offered help.

Have a look at the perks, and whether you decide to participate or not, please help by informing those you know with China interests that this project is underway.

Many thanks.

There's no need for guidebooks to be entirely trivial, to sugar-coat real life, or to highlight only the most appealing aspects of a destination with text that's been manipulated to match carefully cropped and Photoshopped images.
A guidebook should be something you reach for not only for opening hours, ticket prices, and transport information, but because of its readable background material, engaging stories, and fresh research that together advance enjoyment and understanding of a destination.   As Time said of the first edition:
A great guidebook... an infectious, informative read.
The second will be nearly twice the size, and the intention is that it should be twice as good.
Why ask for so little?
Obviously $5,000 is not remotely enough to cover the costs of several weeks' research in Beijing, not to mention further time at the keyboard and the necessary fact-checking, proof-reading, editing, and web page design, all of which are best done by those who know how, leaving me to concentrate on the text. But there's a determination to get this done, and it seems best to look for a very modest contribution and then try to exceed that target if at all possible.
Publishers now typically pay a flat fee for a city guide of only about $8,000, so it's perhaps unsurprising that few well-qualified writers want to tackle this work, and that many guidebooks suffer as their authors attempt to complete them as quickly as possible.
But in this case, $8,000 would actually be very helpful in enhancing the amount of professional assistance to be used, and beyond that in sending out review copies and generating the publicity that will see the book in more people's hands. If we exceed $8000 then delivery of all copies to those choosing a $50 perk or higher will be post-free.
More funding still would also allow for updates to be incorporated swiftly in the months after first publication—one of the benefits of using print-on-demand technology.   $15,000+ would improve the book further, and make it possible to produce multiple updates, perhaps to print parts of the work as standalone volumes intended as supplements to other guides or to produce a companion volume on two- to three-day trips from Beijing or to revise and reissue China: The Silk Routes.
In general, the more funds, the better the results will be.  
The perks
This project is about not letting useful information go to waste, but putting it into the hands of as many people as possible. So the rewards take the form of the book itself, or the book with added extras.   It will be an 8.5" x 5.5" trade paperback, and looks likely to run to nearly 700 pages in the new design, with no space wasted on pretty pictures. Its contents include:

Fuller details of more sights of interest than any other current guide; several walking routes around little-visited sections of traditional housing and along less-known sections of the Great Wall; descriptions of multiple day trips into the surrounding countryside with information on travel options from public transport, through Chinese bus tours, to one-day taxi hires; all with detailed directions in both English and in Chinese characters, and GPS data 

Reading on everything: the lives of the palace eunuchs; corruption in China's modern art scene; the damage caused by UNESCO World Heritage Listing in China; myths about the Great Wall; the keeping of insects as pets; the true story of the Anglo-French destruction of the Summer Palace; the expulsion of Starbucks from the Forbidden City; the Boxer Rebellion, the former brothel quarter of Qian Men; and much more 

Extremely detailed practical advice on health, transport, visas, and more, enabling readers to tackle the city entirely on their own and without needing a word of Mandarin; and whether travelling independently or on a guided tour to avoid Beijing's common scams 

A shopping section with detailed advice on when to bargain in China and exactly how to do it there; details on how to obtain the best hotel rates and domestic air ticket prices, and how to negotiate day-trip hires with taxis. Any of this information might save visitors several multiples of the book’s cover price 

Comprehensive reviews of hostels and hotels from rock-bottom to palatial, and from revamped traditional courtyards to the spartan but business-friendly; a restaurant section that introduces the immense variety of Chinese regional cuisines now available in the capital and which provides all the characters necessary to order recommended dishes; further coverage of cheap street food, food courts, and the best from overseas 

A language section that provides all the characters visitors really need to get what they want; tone-marked pinyin and characters throughout to aid those who have learnt some Mandarin to be understood; a directory of all the attractions around each individual metro stop; a concise and readable history of the city; and much more. 
As the book’s final weight is currently unknown, postage and packing will be payable at net cost via PayPal at the time of dispatch (by your choice of surface, standard air mail, or faster means if preferred).   Canadians may also have to pay GST.
BONUS: If we exceed $8,000, then postage and packing will be FREE to all those who have chosen the $50 perk or higher.
Thanks are already due to Marina Dodis (www.marinadodis.com) for use of the only decent still images in an otherwise amateur video, and to professional cover designer, editor, web designer, and food critic friends and colleagues who have all offered help.
Have a look at the perks, and whether you decide to participate or not, please help by informing those you know with China interests that this project is underway.Many thanks.

story:
February 2013 Update!

Ciao amici! With just a few days left in the campaign, it is unlikely that I'll meet my goal of $3,600. But I've raised enough for plane tickets, so there's no turning back. Cosa Nostra, here I come!

The book will be published, and it will contain the photos I take in this final shoot in Sicily. But it's not too late to join the campaign and help offset expenses.

Closeout sale: Starting now, you can contribute at any level (yes, even at $5) to get on the private email list! You'll receive reports from the field as I run around Mafia zones trying to get the shot without getting shot. I exaggerate, of course, but these trips are always an adventure.

My two biggest challenges on this trip (besides money, and the unexpected) will be snowy mountain passes and trying to photograph locations in two mob-heavy cities I've never visited: Cannicattì & Favara.

Advance praise: "Carl Russo’s The Sicilian Mafia: A True Crime Travel Guide is a seminal piece of work that manages to bridge the gap between John Dickie’s Cosa Nostra and Lonely Planet Sicily." — Crozier Green, author of The Fratellanza Contract and Gladio Resurrection.

(Mr. Green read an advance draft of the book and suggested a new subtitle for the book. My publishers and I really dig it, so we're replacing the rather generic ...An Illustrated Travel Guide. I thank Mr. Green.)

My Unusual Project

In spring of 2006, the people of Sicily were celebrating more than the passing of another cruel winter. Italy's most-wanted Mafia chief, Bernardo Provenzano, had just been arrested after 43 years on the run. The headlines read like pulp fiction: Mafia godfather nabbed in shack outside Corleone surrounded by religious icons.

I happened to be traveling across the island a few weeks after Provenzano's capture. The godfather's shack: I had to see it! After two days of pestering Corleonese baristas and hotel staff, I located the tiny adobe hovel in the mountains above that Mafia stronghold of fact and fiction.

But that wasn't all. I was suddenly seized with the desire to see the place where the bullet-ridden body of the bandit Giuliano was photographed by reporters back in 1950. Where was that?

"There oughta be a book," I said. Famous last words.

First came the blog, Mafia Exposed, filled with my photos of Sicilian Mafia hotspots: murder sites, police massacres, mob homes, hangouts, hideouts, the gravesites of dons and victims alike. The images are accompanied by my heavily researched essays.

Some have been published under a pseudonym at Sabotage Times.

But the blog contains only a portion of my work. There is so much more.

Then came the book deal.

The Sicilian Mafia: A True Crime Travel Guide will be released in January 2014 by Strategic Media Books. The softcover book is projected to have 275 pages and approximately 200 black-and-white photographs.

Despite the book deal, there is no money for a final trip to collect the last batch of locations. That's where you come in!

A Mafia "travel guide?"

Sicily's position in the middle of Mediterranean trade routes made its people prey for numerous foreign powers through the millennia. Despite its unfortunate history, the island is unsurpassed in beautiful historical monuments, from ancient Greek temples to baroque churches. And don't forget beaches like paradise and food from heaven! Anyone who visits Sicily will never forget the experience.

Unfortunately, it is also synonymous with the Cosa Nostra, an ongoing phenomenon related to its turbulent past. What may seem to some like an insensitive book project is actually a way of shedding light on the problem. And light is always deleterious to the Mafia.

We're all interested in stories of the Mafia. No sense in denying our curiosity about criminality. Dozens of books about the Mafia are published each year in Italy, more than in any other country. To be sure, they are lurid. But they are written with respect for the victims and in solidarity with the strong anti-Mafia movement in that country.

It is in that spirit that I present the very first Sicilian Mafia travel guide in any language. No hotels or restaurant reviews. Just the down and dirty about locations you can see on your own travels, whether in Sicily or from the comfort of your armchair.

Take the journey with me

Contributing to this campaign at $25 and above will put you on my private email list. You'll receive missives from the field as I work undercover in Mafialand. I have many tried-and-true methods for "getting the shot," but anything can happen. I am full of stories about my previous adventures.

I'm also offering a late draft of the book on PDF file months before the book launch. There are also signed photos at the upper levels. This is good for everyone who has already contributed at those levels.

This is not a vacation. I start working the moment I'm handed the car keys at the Palermo airport. No beach time. No museums. Like any location shoot, it's a battle for daylight.

Fortunately for my contributors, I have perfected low-budget travel in Sicily, not the least of which is going in the low season. One constant is that food, car rental and gas bill are about equal for a ten-day trip (gas is nearly $9 a gallon, and I rack up the miles each day). Here's a rough breakdown of the $3,600 budget:

 

Airfare  $1500

Hotels  $500

Car Rental  $400

Fuel  $400

Food  $400

Fees & Taxes  $400

________________

TOTAL  $3,600

 

Be an anti-Mafia activist

If you can't contribute money, please put your best social media skills to use and get the word out. Indiegogo makes it easy with its share-tools for posting on your media and websites. You can also follow me on Facebook, Twitter and at my home base, Mafia Exposed, as well as through campaign updates, clickable above.

But if you can contribute money, fire away!

 

Grazzî e nni videmu!

(Thanks and see ya!)

 

Video footage and music legally licensed.

story:
Everyone, and their dog, seems ready to decry that there is something wrong in our world.

Aren’t you bored with cynical clichés? I am. Not because everything is okay, but because we make our own reality. This requires action, practice; not world-weary remarks.

This book will attempt to codify what is not working, followed by things we can do about it; not in some theoretical realm beyond personal influence, but in action each of us can do now. Starting with the way we think.

The Industrial Age Is Over

For the Ford factory to work, it needs workers and consumers. As long as those two exist then factories can keep spitting cars out, and the economy will keep growing.

This worked well for a few generations. Kids went to school, learned how to memorize, repeat, and make no errors. They then became reliable workers, cogs in some part of a plant. They married, consumed and procreated.

As long as you did as told, there was a house, wife, kids and dog allotted for you. For the process to work, it needs to be reliable. No risks, no failures. If you screwed up, it was your fault.

Then Thatcher and Reagan came to power and sent all manufacturing off-shore. Any work piece that could be turned into a repeatable process, was broken down, codified and sent to cheap workers around the globe.

It’s been going on for decades; the industrial model is disappearing from the Western World. And if we are to adapt, we need some urgent change too.

There is not too much we can change about the education we received. What we can do is rethink how we live the rest of our lives.

Instead of procreating new workers and consumers, we can pause and be. Instead of consuming, we can pull back and sustain. Instead of merely working, we can start creating.

There is no process or instructions for that. We need to stick our neck out. We need to fail before we have a chance in making it. We need to learn. Be creative.

This book is a manifesto for wholesome living.

Approach

Since publishing my previous book, “Mind Bind” last June, I focused on creating a potent online platform, via my blog. It’s now time to structure it all into one cohesive, readable and useful unit. I.e. a book.
  • I will self-publish. Vying for the attention of publishers is time and soul consuming. Need more reasons to self-publish? Read the best post on this topic by James Altucher.
  • There will be some illustration. This will include sketches I make. As needed, I may turn to professional help too, but the aim is to keep costs low.
  • The book’s thematic red-line will map to the Creatively Maladjusted Manifesto. I may make tweaks to reflect how the idea grew since its inception.
  • The aim of the book is to be one short cohesive read. It will develop and flow as a singular idea, and not a collection of random posts.
  • Ergo, I will create significant amounts of new but related content, whilst existing online work will need to be refreshed, cleaned-up, and updated.
  • I will use iA Writer for capturing new text. I will try Scrivener to manage existing blocks of content in one cohesive project. Same as with “Mind Bind”, I will use Adobe InDesign for formatting and presentation for both print and Kindle exports. OmniGraffle will be used as needed for diagrams. As for iPad I intend to try Apple’s iBooks Author, but we’re nowhere near that stage yet.
  • I will post regular updates of my work on my blog. This will a) keep me accountable and motivated and b) encourage feedback and contributions from interested friends.

story:
Atomic Tourism!

Hi, I’m Anne, and I’m an Atomic Tourist and Writer (my business cards even say so). What the heck does this mean? Well, I visit sites important to the Atomic Age—fallout shelters, atomic blast sites, secret cities—and then write about them. In fact the fine folks over at McSweeney’s even let me write a column about the stuff. Here's a link to my column.

So why do I do this? First, I’m a very nerdy lady who happens to be fascinated by nuclear science, particularly the stuff of the Atomic Age. In other words, Anne’s Wheelhouse = Nuclear Stuff. Second, we’re forgetting about the Atomic Age. I want to do what I can to prevent the Atomic Age from sliding headlong into the shadows of the conspiracy theory set. It’s interesting! And entertaining! Let’s remember it!

My aim is to enlighten and entertain everyone with some really cool travel writing about some awesomely nerdy, downright wacky at times, nearly forgotten places from our history.

I’ve been to a good number of Atomic Tourist sites, but am quickly making it through my stockpile of visited sites to use as topics for my column, and low on funds to visit more. This is where you come in dear friends! With your help, I can visit additional, and even more exotic (look out Pennsylvania!), atomic tourist sites and continue to write about them in my column, turning the whole thing into an informative and entertaining book.

Plan

I have narrowed down my list of sites to visit to seven. There are many, many more sites to visit than this, but one bite of the atomic pie at a time.

Depending on funds earned, I plan on visiting the following sites, in the following order:

1.  New Mexico

  • The Trinity Test Site is the site where the first atomic bomb was tested in 1945.
  • The National Museum of Nuclear Science and History, well duh.
  • Los Alamos Historical Museum (Manhattan Project).
  • Bradbury Science Museum (Manhattan Project).

2.  Oak Ridge, Tennessee

Secret City Festival!

Oak Ridge, Tennessee was a secret, factory-built town where a lot of the Manhattan Project was carried out. Now, they have an arts and crafts festival, and tours of the sites every spring! There's probably fair food!

3.  Washington DC and West Virginia

The Smithsonian, well duh.

The Greenbrier Resort is home to the once secret congressional fallout shelter. The shelter is part of the resort, and was super secret until a few years ago when information about the site was leaked. Now you can tour it for thirty bucks!

4.  Palm Beach, Florida

The Kennedy Fallout Shelter, which is kind of in a cave? On an island? I have to see it.

5.  Hanford, Washington

The Hanford Site is a mostly decommissioned nuclear production site. The first plutonium production reactor lives here. Plutonium from this site was used in the first atomic bomb as well as Fat Man, which was used on Nagasaki.

6.  Pennsylvania and New Jersey

  • Three Mile Island was the site of a kind of awful nuclear accident in 1979.
  • The Radium Girls were factory girls who painted radioactive paint on clock dials. Many of the girls suffered from the exposure to radiation. Five of the girls sued the company they worked for. The occupational disease labor law is a direct result of this lawsuit.

Stretch Goal

If I make over $5000, I will visit…

7.  Chernobyl!

Basically the Holy Grail of Atomic Tourism.

  • The Chernobyl nuclear power plant in Ukraine, suffered a catastrophic accident in 1986. A lot of radiation was released during the accident and the surrounding area was evacuated for decades. The area has recently reopened for guided tours.
  • Chernobyl is in a faraway land and will be relatively expensive to visit. I’ll only be able to visit the site if I exceed funding for this project.

What will I do with your money?

Your money will help me to visit these sites and continue to write about them in my column, with the intent of turning the column into a book in the next year or so.

Your money will help in the following ways:

Transportation

  • Gas and car maintenance for locations within driving distance.
  • Airfare for locations outside of driving distance.

Room and Board

  • Funds for stays at decent hotels. Decent is about equidistant between murdery and five star resort on my hotel spectrum. I will not stay anywhere fancy-pants (except the Greenbrier, which is basically the definition of hoity-toity but it’s an atomic tourist site in its own right) just places that are safe and clean for a lady traveling alone.
  • Funds for food. Again, I won’t go crazy with your money dining at fancy-pants Michelin-starred places.

Atomic Tourist Site Entrance/Tour Fees

  • Some places charge a fee to view the atomic goodness within. Most are small, though they quickly add-up.

Writing-Related Expenses

  • Though I’m at the very start of the book writing process, I may need to use funds for the actual book writing/editing/making/publishing once the time comes.

Miscellaneous

  • Any unexpected fees popping-up during atomic touring.

I've opted for the Flexible Funding option. This means that any money donated during the campaign will be mine to use, even if the funding goal is not met. So, any little bit counts!

Rewards

I have lots of cool perks (or at least I think they’re cool) for contributors of all different levels.

The Impact

History! Learning! Writing!

We’re going to forget about this stuff is someone doesn’t write it down. I’m the writer-downer, I’ve made a really good start over at McSweeney’s, but I need your help to continue. And to write a book!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you’re unable to help in a financial way, please consider spreading the word about my project on Twitter, Facebook, the bulletin board at your local coffee shop, your website, Tumblr, Google +, or any other online/offline medium you can think of.

And read my column at McSweeney’s! Tell your friends how awesome it is!

Adventures in Atomic Tourism: http://www.mcsweeneys.net/columns/are-you-telling-me-that-this-suckers-nuclear-adventures-in-atomic-tourism

The Kennedy Fallout Shelter, which is kind of in a cave? On an island? I have to see it.
5.  Hanford, Washington
The Hanford Site is a mostly decommissioned nuclear production site. The first plutonium production reactor lives here. Plutonium from this site was used in the first atomic bomb as well as Fat Man, which was used on Nagasaki.
6.  Pennsylvania and New Jersey

Three Mile Island was the site of a kind of awful nuclear accident in 1979.
The Radium Girls were factory girls who painted radioactive paint on clock dials. Many of the girls suffered from the exposure to radiation. Five of the girls sued the company they worked for. The occupational disease labor law is a direct result of this lawsuit.
Stretch Goal
If I make over $5000, I will visit…
7.  Chernobyl!
Basically the Holy Grail of Atomic Tourism.

The Chernobyl nuclear power plant in Ukraine, suffered a catastrophic accident in 1986. A lot of radiation was released during the accident and the surrounding area was evacuated for decades. The area has recently reopened for guided tours.
Chernobyl is in a faraway land and will be relatively expensive to visit. I’ll only be able to visit the site if I exceed funding for this project.
What will I do with your money?
Your money will help me to visit these sites and continue to write about them in my column, with the intent of turning the column into a book in the next year or so.
Your money will help in the following ways:
Transportation

Gas and car maintenance for locations within driving distance.
Airfare for locations outside of driving distance.
Room and Board

Funds for stays at decent hotels. Decent is about equidistant between murdery and five star resort on my hotel spectrum. I will not stay anywhere fancy-pants (except the Greenbrier, which is basically the definition of hoity-toity but it’s an atomic tourist site in its own right) just places that are safe and clean for a lady traveling alone.
Funds for food. Again, I won’t go crazy with your money dining at fancy-pants Michelin-starred places.
Atomic Tourist Site Entrance/Tour Fees

Some places charge a fee to view the atomic goodness within. Most are small, though they quickly add-up.
Writing-Related Expenses

Though I’m at the very start of the book writing process, I may need to use funds for the actual book writing/editing/making/publishing once the time comes.
Miscellaneous

Any unexpected fees popping-up during atomic touring.
I've opted for the Flexible Funding option. This means that any money donated during the campaign will be mine to use, even if the funding goal is not met. So, any little bit counts!
Rewards
I have lots of cool perks (or at least I think they’re cool) for contributors of all different levels.
The Impact
History! Learning! Writing!
We’re going to forget about this stuff is someone doesn’t write it down. I’m the writer-downer, I’ve made a really good start over at McSweeney’s, but I need your help to continue. And to write a book!
Other Ways You Can Help
If you’re unable to help in a financial way, please consider spreading the word about my project on Twitter, Facebook, the bulletin board at your local coffee shop, your website, Tumblr, Google +, or any other online/offline medium you can think of.
And read my column at McSweeney’s! Tell your friends how awesome it is!
Adventures in Atomic Tourism: http://www.mcsweeneys.net/columns/are-you-telling-me-that-this-suckers-nuclear-adventures-in-atomic-tourism

story:
Short Summary

Back in June of 2012, whilst the world was seemingly heading towards an apocalypse, I had a moment of clarity and said "Enough. I’m never gonna work for the Man again." At that same time, a woman whose opinion I respect read my master's thesis and told me, "You are a writer. You NEED to write." And then I had a motorcycle accident, which was actually destiny calling. 

I was given $800/month of disability, and with nothing else to do, I followed my heart and it led me to Valparaiso, Chile. There I immersed myself in the art and craft of fiction, poetry and theater, and the city's pulse became my own. 

I wanted to write non-fiction, a handbook for how to live out my pet-philosophy, pan-experientialism (everything is somewhat sentient), but instead focused on my own experience in that wild town, and began experimenting with the idea of life as fiction--a novel we create--weaving together our stories with the stories of friends, enemies, neighbors and lovers. Valparaiso is a poet's garden, an organic, throbbing city, a place that has always resisted the prototypical Spanish urge to contain space in neat, square columns and rows. The labyrinths of graffiti, the hills rising up from the bay, the constant presence of music and art, and most of all the colorful characters that call Valparaiso home, all inspired me to use my heart as a compass, and see what I could find. It was a glorious time.  

Then I ran out of money, and came back. I did earn a few piasters this summer working for Outward Bound, and as a guide in Yosemite, but I still need some help to support my new habit of telling tales of an emerging paradigm. I am launching myself in the direction of destiny, and you are my rocket fuel.  The definition of adventure is that success is not assured. I booked my flight back to Chile with the certainty that it WAS the place I needed to write but without full resources to complete the work. I have a manuscript in hand, but it needs to have the breath of Valparaiso blown into it. That's why I'm leaving, to follow in the footsteps of Miller, Kerouac, Steinbeck and Robbins, to set out on the mystic highway, riding the tip of the spear, piercing the veil that hides not only the essence of everything around us, but keeps us from knowing even our own true selves. I invite you to join me on this playful, yet evocative journey of mind, body and soul in the California that might have been, a Paradise for those who thought they’d lost it —Valparaiso, Chile. 

What I Need & What You Get

I booked the cheapest flight I could find for Chile, knowing that I didn't have enough funds to sustain me for very long. Work there is poorly-paid, and I am investing that time in my future by completing this, my first novel. 

Your support will allow me to live for a few months in South America, where I can bring the process to a finish. Upon my return in the Spring, I will see that the work gets published, either by an actual publishing house, or if need be, by my own hand. Every level of support will result in you getting a signed 1st edition copy of the novel, and the satisfaction that you helped me to achieve this somewhat weighty goal. I thank you in advance for your generosity and love. 

The Impact

The purpose of a novel, according to Milan Kundera, is to reveal some aspect of life that has hitherto remained hidden. In this work, I am experimenting with 'real' life--to what extent do we determine what happens to us? Where does one's will end and the world come in? What is the power of the word? Do the stories we tell ourselves really make a difference? How can we create the experience of paradise in our lives here on Earth? 

This all began from an environmentalist's perspective, some years back. What I've discovered is that we are in great need of a shift in VALUES, specifically from materialism to non-materialism. We need to value our EXPERIENCE primarily, and other's experience of us. I believe that reading this book will help people to "get it."

Endorsements

"A perfect symphony of poetry and philosophy, Matteo's writing is the music we need for a this new age. Matteo possesses the provocative ideas, the unique voice, and the intellectual fortitude to be one of the greats. We need a new voice in this empty cultural and materialistic wilderness to connect us all. I think this book has the potential to change the soul of society." 

--Beth Pratt, author and California Director of the National Wildlife Society

"I am delighted that the world still makes people like this!"

--Malcolm Margolin, author and publisher, Heyday Books

Other Ways You Can Help 

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the good word!
  • Ask your parents for an early Christmas present (or are you too naughty!?!)
  • Visualize my success (and your own!)

story:
Help PlayGround Publications publish this year’s anthology of the season’s best scripts by pre-ordering a copy of The Best of PlayGround-Los Angeles (2013)


THE BACKSTORY

Since 1994, the mission of PlayGround has been to support the development of new voices for the theatre. For almost two decades, PlayGround has been a leading playwright incubator, providing unique opportunities for the cultivation and development of early-career local playwrights and partnerships with leading professional directors, actors, theatres and theatre lovers. In 2012, PlayGround expanded to Los Angeles with the launch of PlayGround-LA and its inaugural season in residence at the Zephyr Theatre.

Through the development of original short (and eventually full-length) plays, PlayGround-LA creates a microcosm of the greater theatre scene, supporting emerging playwrights' experimentation and risk-taking, while helping them hone their style and technique.


PUBLISH OR PERISH

For the past twelve years, PlayGround Publications has promoted the work of scores of emerging new playwrights and their short plays through the Best of PlayGround series of anthologies.

In mid-May, PlayGround Publications will print two new Best of PlayGround 2013 anthologies. You can help us in this mission by pre-ordering copies of the Los Angeles book through this Indiegogo funding campaign.

The book contains six scripts as performed at this year’s Best of PlayGround Gala new plays showcase (May 13, 2013). These six plays were selected as the best this season from more than 100 submissions and thirty-six works developed through the Monday Night PlayGround staged reading series.

Each script is printed in its entirety, creating an historical record of the development of these plays, with dates of first reading and premiere, original casting information and playwright biographies.

Proceeds of this funding campaign will be used exclusively to print and distribute the Best of PlayGround Los Angeles anthology.

The Best of PlayGround anthologies:

  • Celebrate the best short plays of the past season;
  • Provide an economical way to bring high-quality audience-tested scripts to the attention of producers and educators;
  • Promote the work of new generations of talented playwrights;
  • Provide students and new dramatists with models of plays that have proven popular with audiences;
  • Creates an historical record of the development of these plays.

This year PlayGround is expanding the role of these books to help move the work of its talented emerging writers from page and into production.

The 2013 Los Angeles anthology contains complete scripts of the following plays:

Romeo and Jules by Ron Burch
Pinocchia by Kathleen Cecchin
The Kid in the Trunk by John Corcoran, Jr.
The Prince and the Closet Castle by Andrew Crabtree
Waiting for Kafka by Kevin Crust
Flight Time by Carolina Rojas Moretti


CUT TO THE CHASE

By contributing to our campaign, you can pre-order copies of this year’s anthology which will be available in mid-May, 2013. This frees PlayGround-LA to invest its working capital in developing and producing the best new plays by Los Angeles's best new playwrights.

In addition to pre-ordering an anthology, if you are able to contribute more, we’ve lined up some swell perks as our way of saying thank you. If you'd like to pre-order multiple copies, please contact us for special rates.

Even though a great deal of in-kind labor is donated to support this publishing project, there’s no avoiding the need for cold, hard cash.

PlayGround Publications will use proceeds of this campaign to:

  • Print the 2013 Best of PlayGround-Los Angeles anthology;
  • Acquire ISBN numbers (yes, they cost money);
  • Market the anthologies to producers, educators, drama students, and fans of the theatre;
  • Create and distribute electronic versions of the anthologies.

Please support our campaign and help us jump-start the careers of some exciting new voices in the theatre community. Thank you!



PlayGround Publications is a fiscally-sponsored project of PlayGround (Federal ID 94-3336399). All gifts to this campaign are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.

story:
*I'll be updating the campaign video soon. This clip was a response to NASA's prompt to ask the International Space Station 30 second questions on youtube during the first google live chat in space. Thanks for checking out my campaign letter below! * 
 
Dear Friends,
 

I'll be turning 25 this year, and all I want for my first quarter century is the freedom to write. I've been working through a series of promising drafts but need some  time to collect my own thoughts. When I started this campaign, I needed to raise $3,000 to cover the 2 month summer break in my job. I have since secured a part time job to cover part of those costs, but still need your help! Your contributions will help pay rent, health insurance, and other necessities to support my writing during this time. More importantly, they will also allow me to move from a 347 sq. ft. studio to a one bedroom apartment within walking distance from work. I need this added space to house my first kitchen table and writing desk, and to feel a bit more like myself as i'm starting to grown again.  Here are a few of the projects i'm working on and how you can help! 

A Screenplay Called "Near Death Experiences":

"Near Death Experinces" is a  coming of age story about wrestling new frontiers in our everyday lives, or average existences, as seen from a transgender child’s view. Its about using play to work through those narratives and trying to understand our own pasts. The story draws on many elements of local history-- from the space race to  old western images-- to challenge the bounds of whats possible and question our progress collectively. As many of you know, this project also took on new meaning for me when my friend passed away several weeks ago. So, it is also a very personal story, as I explore my own pasts in this place [C. Springs] and in queer/trans movements more generally. I've never written a screenplay before, so I welcome opportunities to collaborate or discuss this new medium, and would love to host a dialogue on the challenges inherant to writing it-- from questions about cultural reapropriation to the pressure of producing a draft for funding purposes.  I also have a lot to give back and teach in this conversation, based on my academinc work on transgender history and politics and my work as a facilitator for the TransCampus project.

  • You can sponsor a 10 page autoethnography for Near Death Experiences, or any 10 page story on the theme of your choice, for only $50! Ill send each sponsor a signed and bound copy of my favorite 5 stories by Christmas time. I only need 5 sponsors to make this perk possible! 

A  Written Work with Multi-Site Installation /Performance Called M-Theory:

“M-Theory” is a re-telling of the relationship between Mary and Christ, staged in the big bang of our universe. This largely experimental project has been in the works for nearly two years, and I am only just now beginning to understand its significance within my own writing practices. While part of this project engages written forms such as prose and poetry, there is also a performative element that i am beginning to explore in multiple mediums. This summer, I hope to bring together a series of staged Sunday sermons that re-position the storyteller as a community organizer / activist who is not tied to traditional sites, methods, or narratives around social justice work, which presents its own barriers to the construction of social change. One of these staged Sunday sermons is partially inspired by Dr. Cornell West's talk "The Gifts of Black Folk in the Age of Terrorism". I hope to draw on my thesis work to write on the critical gifts of queer/trans communities and hope it will inform my work on Near Death Experiences. If theatrical sermons arent your thing, i'm also writing a show in my tub about the resurrection and baptism that's meant to be viewed from outside my window sill. If you'd rather I come to a party near you, just ask about my travelling preacher piece!  

  • You can sponsor a Sunday sermon, tub talk, or other performance for only $100. I'll send each sponsor a signed and bound copy of 3 or more sermons or other performances by Christmas time. I only need 3 sponsors to make this perk possible! 


Creative Economy: 

I'm interested in re-defining our personal and collective economies to create a better community. This project is about building and mapping relationships as I explore diverse forms and systems of capital-- social, economic, and otherwise.  I've sometimes struggled to build strong, intimate and/personally meaningful relationships in C. Springs, so this is an individual attempt to circualte ideas and resources more creatively and with greater autonomy than normative structures sometimes allow.

  • Creative economies dont always need cash! But, if that's what you're here to give, you can sponsor a summer's worth of moleskines, sketchpads, pens, paints, and other supplies for only $150. Choose your perk!
    • A) Ill send you you an original, 18 x 24 handwritten poster exploring the idea of your choice and mail a letter each month for a year. 
    • B) I will work with you one-on-one for up to 6 hours collaboration on the writing component  of one of your projects via email or Skype.
    • C) Make me an offer to trade money, skills, ideas, and or services by phone or email using my contact information below. Be sure to contact me before signing up if you choose option C :) 

 

Bonus! Creative Economy Starter Kit-- Skeptical but willing to invest in my work? Interested but still strapped for cash? No problem! For $30, I'll mail you hand copied reproductions of 3 moleskine pages [pocket sized = great postcards] with a signed 1 page letter connecting the dots / significance of the seeminly disparate messages I select. Add a copy of your starter kit to send to your friends for only $10 each! It sounds like a silly fun to game to me.

If you have any questions or find this work interesting, i'd love to hear from you. Feel free to reach out at anytime, and thanks for supporting me.

 

Best, 

Adison Quin Petti

720-862-6126

adison.petti@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

This is a book about turning your great idea into an actual business and includes many antidotes and stories from my personal experiences and businesses that I have worked with and for.

I recently started my own consulting business where I work with small businesses mainly with finances, but also with marketings, sales, brand development, and HR. I got the idea for the book from starting to blog about business topics on my business website (www.brownconsultingwork.com).

If you are interested, you can view a chapter preview on my website...

What We Need & What You Get

The goal for this first round of 60 days is to raise $500 for the first run of published books. I have chosen to publish the book myself in hardback as well as paperback through an online publishing/printing company. 100% of the money raised will go towards publishing costs. The more money that is raise, the more books I am able to initially publish.

The reason for the campaign here is to obviously raise money to help finance the publishing cost. Just like most normal people, I do not have a spare $2,000 or $3,000 to publish everything all at once, so I am looking at doing this in stages. The book is in the editing process currently and should be ready for pick up in Dec 2013.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute actual money, I understand. But please take 3 seconds out of your day and share this campaign with your friends on Facebook, the word of mouth, or other social media websites. Your sharing will go a long way in helping me try to reach my goal.

story:
The Prologue

(Morningstar:) "Sometimes we aren't sure what our purpose is - what we’re here to do. We go through most of our lives not knowing what we want or believing we can get it, until one day we wake up no longer leading our lives, but being led by them... by others. Like self-made, masochistic marionettes, we drive razor-sharp hooks deep into our emotions, our fears, our insecurities, and then hand over the strings to anyone who fits the profile of a crazed bull in a china shop. I used to be like that; the strings had been in others’ hands so long I couldn't remember how they were tied to me in the first place so I could pull the damn things out and finally taste the freedom from the darkness my eroding soul craved. But that’s the beauty about living in total darkness – even the faintest light can be seen, no matter how far away it is. The hard part for most of us, is taking those first steps towards it...

Those first steps were as invisible as the wind to me; I couldn't see the path before me, but I knew one was there. Some people seek advice in their time of need, but trust was not a luxury to me. Maybe it was my pride, or confidence, or the shattered fragments of a past too trusting. Either way, it really doesn't matter, because I know life is what you make it and legacy is how you leave it. Stop trying to be perfect, stop waiting for perfection to find you, and start making your environment a product of you instead of the other way around.

If you want to break out of your cycle of disappointment, listen closely; wait too long, and the only disappointment will be you. There are two kinds of people in the world: the puppets and the puppeteers. I'm not going to give you any generalized advice like that self-help nonsense, because generalized advice is about as useful as poisons and blades are in the hands of the inexperienced. No - instead, let me tell you a story, my story, so you can know specifically what happened and draw the conclusions you need for yourself. You’re smarter than you think with more potential than you know; realize this, and your rebirth will rival that of a phoenix from the ashes; you will know as I know, that true captivity lies not in the hands of those above you, nor around you, but within you. Break the chains that your independence has come to know all-too-well, and the world, and everything in it, can be yours."

 

What "Rise of the Morningstar" (the book) is about

"Rise of the Morningstar", the first book in a five-book series, is the story of a good guy's evolution to villainy. It begins with Morningstar, a hard-working good guy who realizes his life isn't going quite how he wants it to; he works hard, but it seems like no matter how hard he works or how good he is, things just don't go his way. At his breaking point, he goes all-for-broke and starts taking back control of his life, soon realizing the power of his choices. But those choices do not come without consequence; the more he changes things and starts to manipulate the people around him, the more it begins to change him as well, and he finds it harder and harder to remain the good guy...

For excerpts from the book, scroll to the bottom of this page!

Who this "A. J. Darkholme" (the author) guy is

A. J. Darkholme is an author, poet, tech-enthusiast, philosopher, teacher, entrepreneur, pun-master, and daydreamer extraordinaire! But behind all that, for those who know me, it is the "pen name" I will write under as the experiences of my life merge with the stories of my imagination to produce stories as deep, insightful, and informative as they are entertaining. There's nothing I'd love more than to start a career where I can help people bring positive changes to their lives through poetic prose; to help people recalibrate their thinking and emotional releases into productive outlets that lace the path of their future with jewels instead of potholes.

Feel free to follow my career as it develops at:
http://www.mistero.co/aj-darkholme/
http://www.facebook.com/ajdarkholme
@AJDarkholme (https://www.twitter.com/ajdarkholme)

Hope to see you there!

How this campaign came to be

Have you ever reached a point in your life where you wonder if where you are is where you're meant to be? I think when we start asking ourselves that question, we become gatekeepers to a world of possibility: a world where dreams don't have to be limited to imagination, but can be made reality.

The thing is, when you look for advice on this kind of thing, it's usually pretty sappy and lame, or is an untimely force-fed lesson taught by someone who hasn't really learned it and lived it themselves. We're observant, stubborn hopefuls, and that's just how most of us roll. Teenagers rebel because they are frustrated with the people around them and want to learn and do things for themselves without being told they can't or when they need to be done something by. And as adults... well, we're mostly just more experienced, better-paid teenagers. Either way, we're all looking to define ourselves and find a purpose in life that can make us happy.

Realizing this, especially balancing my experience as a teacher with my experience as a worker bee in a corporate cubicle, I started observing the world a little more closely, trying to pin-point how people learn most effectively and what gives them the most happiness. And you know what I found? You know what the secret is?

People like to be entertained.

There is freedom in entertainment: a reality that feels like an escape from reality. When we're entertained, we're much more willing to listen to - and sometimes even *do* - almost anything someone says because we're engaged in the appeal and charisma of it.

So I wrote a book - a "self-help fantasy" book - full of grounded, purpose-imbuing advice, interlaced with well-researched Psychology concepts, all tied together under a mask of entertainment. It reads like Harry Potter or Twilight (Well maybe not Twilight so much... lol) on the surface, but subliminally teaches you how to reconcile with your past, accept the present, and not just wonder about your future, but show you how to make it a direct and expected result of what you start doing today.

Interested? Pledge and contribute to make the dream a reality!

What I need & what you'll get

The book is SUPER close to being fully written! But when a self-publishing author is finished writing, that's when the free-ride is over and some money is needed to take the story from the hard drive to the book stores! I need about $5000 - $7000 in total, broken up as follows:

  • Proofreading - ~$250
  • Professional editing (the major cost) - $0.04/word doesn't sound like much at first, but with an 80,000 word novel, it works out to be about $3200.
  • Cover design/layout - ~$450
  • Cover artist - $500 (Shichigoro, an amazing artist in Japan) 
  • Interior design/writing layout - ~$250
  • ISBN Number - Free for Canada (yay!), $125 for each individual ISBN in the US ($250 for a bundle of 10)
  • Printer/Distributor Setup Fees - I've chosen Lightning Source as my printing/distributing company, who charges $75 for this.
  • Distribution - $12+/year for online distribution (Print-On-Demand). Depending how much you pledge, I can also publish in different countries and continents for more wide-spread distribution!
  • A proof copy - $30 (including shipping). This is the final printed copy to look at and read through before it's made fully sellable.
  • Promotion/Marketing - ~$5500 (I'll go with a local business in Winnipeg to help the "little guys" stay alive and thrive)

Help me raise *more* than that, and I'll take some of that generousity and put into distribution of free copies to schools and organizations that can't afford to purchase new books! Everything extra will go into marketing and promotion to give it as much of a widespread channel as possible.

As for what you'll get - check out the perks for pledging on the right side! If you have any other ideas or requests, let me know and I'll add it as a new tier!

Some excerpts from the book so far

Since you can't judge a book by it's cover (although it's a pretty awesome cover), here's some of what's inside. The more you help me raise, the more quotes I'll post!

 

Unlocked Excerpt 1: Awareness

"What seems like a flaw is merely our higher consciousness telling us we’re not looking at it in the right light yet."

Unlocked Excerpt 2: Trust

"Trust is not a gasoline-soaked blanket that succumbs to the matches of betrayal, never able to be used for its warmth again; it’s a tapestry that wears thin in places, but can be patched over if you have the right materials, circumstances, and patience to repair it. If you don’t, you’re the one who feels the coldest when Winter comes."

Unlocked Excerpt 3: Purpose

"Some people experience a life-changing sensation that transforms how they see the world after a near-death experience, but the way I see it, we’re all dying – nay, we’re all dead – and it is up to us to be our own self-necromancers to find some form of life and spirit to reanimate the corpse of a life spent wanting."

Unlocked Excerpt 4: Wooing

"A man is no more than breath until his breath fashions the words that others cannot forget. But you my darling, are worthy of words not yet imagined – words woven to perfection from the fibres that make envy grow in the hearts of goddesses. Though such words escape me, your presence has infused into my being every aspect of bliss that a life of happiness demands. Every day that I catch but a glimpse of you renews a satisfaction in me that even the greediest or luckiest men could only hope for, yet never have for themselves, because as long as I get to call you mine, I shall never be found wanting. Since the first time I saw you, my eyes had never presented me with beauty more deserving of the word’s connotations."

Like what you read? Want to see more excerpts? The more you pledge, the more I'll reveal!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

SPREAD THE WORD! Even if you can't contribute, tell everybody you know about this amazing book coming out! Post it in forums, talk to people at bus stops, discuss it with coworkers over coffee, email it to family and friends, write it in bathroom stalls or spraypaint the link to this campaign on buildings! Well, maybe not the last two due to legal ramifications, but if you know me personally, you'll have a connection to a future celebrity to brag to people about haha MAKE SOME NOISE! Use the Indiegogo share tools to pass this on through your social networking sites!

 

More From Darkholme

"Rise of the Morningstar" is a poetic-prose novel, neither one nor the other, but rather a plot interlaced with the best from both. For a glimpse of my poems, check out the ones below, or view others by "liking" my Facebook page to catch the latest when it's fresh off the mind!
